abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is satisfactory
            despite an unlikely sustainability, and moderate
            institutional development impacts. Among the lessons
            learned, project design and policy implications outline the
            project complexity, reflected by in-experiences in civil
            works, and services, and failure to appropriately apply the
            Bank's safeguard policies. Instead, a two-phase project
            design could have better included less complex civil works
            in the first phase, with a second phase including the
            Asuncion ring-road, thus providing time for a thorough
            preparation of the ring-road component. Moreover,
            construction costs were underestimated in the design phase,
            which lead to cost overruns; this could have been prevented
            by preparing the engineering design studies prior to the
            bidding process, to avoid construction delays. Project
            implementation highlights the need to establish early on,
            performance indicators, and key measurable institutional
            indicators, to avoid difficulties in proposing timely
            remedial measures, while organizational capacity should be
            assessed prior to the start of project implementation. In
            addition, the resettlement plan should be prepared well in
            advance of project appraisal, to avoid delays due to a lack
            of financial resources, institutional weakness, and poor
            land tenure and registry systems. Finally, political
            stability should be considered, to attain easy access to
            decision making, and dialogue.
